nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -17,17 +17,17 @@ key and value of the underlying {{ site.ak }} topic message.
 A column is defined by a combination of its [name](#valid-identifiers), its [SQL data type](#sql-data-types),
 and possibly a namespace.
 
-Key columns have a `KEY` or `PRIMARY KEY` suffix for streams and tables, respectively.
-ksqlDB supports a single key column only.
+Key columns have a `KEY` or `PRIMARY KEY` suffix for streams and tables, respectively while value 
+columns have no namespace suffix. There can be multiple columns in either namespace, given that
+the underlying serialization format supports it (the `KAFKA` format, for example, does not).

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -429,10 +439,14 @@ Single field (un)wrapping
 
 ### (de)serialization of single keys
 
-At this time, ksqlDB supports only a single key column and that key columns
-must be unwrapped, i.e. not contained within a outer record or object. See
-the next two sections on single values for more information about wrapped
-and unwrapped data.
+ksqlDB assumes that any single key is unwrapped, i.e. not contained within an outer
+record or object. Conversely, ksqlDB assumes that any key with multiple columns
+(e.g. `CREATE STREAM K1 INT KEY, K2 INT KEY, C1 INT`) is wrapped, i.e is a record

nodes.bodyText:
This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            To declare a single column key that is wrapped, you may specify a `STRUCT` type
          
          
            
            To declare a single-column key that's wrapped, specify a `STRUCT` type
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -429,10 +439,14 @@ Single field (un)wrapping
 
 ### (de)serialization of single keys
 
-At this time, ksqlDB supports only a single key column and that key columns
-must be unwrapped, i.e. not contained within a outer record or object. See
-the next two sections on single values for more information about wrapped
-and unwrapped data.
+ksqlDB assumes that any single key is unwrapped, i.e. not contained within an outer
+record or object. Conversely, ksqlDB assumes that any key with multiple columns
+(e.g. `CREATE STREAM K1 INT KEY, K2 INT KEY, C1 INT`) is wrapped, i.e is a record
+with each column as a field within the key. 
+
+To declare a single column key that is wrapped, you may specify a `STRUCT` type

This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            with a single column (e.g. `K STRUCT<F1 INT> KEY`). See the next two sections 
          
          
            
            with a single column. for example, `K STRUCT<F1 INT> KEY`. See the next two sections
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -429,10 +439,14 @@ Single field (un)wrapping
 
 ### (de)serialization of single keys
 
-At this time, ksqlDB supports only a single key column and that key columns
-must be unwrapped, i.e. not contained within a outer record or object. See
-the next two sections on single values for more information about wrapped
-and unwrapped data.
+ksqlDB assumes that any single key is unwrapped, i.e. not contained within an outer
+record or object. Conversely, ksqlDB assumes that any key with multiple columns
+(e.g. `CREATE STREAM K1 INT KEY, K2 INT KEY, C1 INT`) is wrapped, i.e is a record
+with each column as a field within the key. 
+
+To declare a single column key that is wrapped, you may specify a `STRUCT` type
+with a single column (e.g. `K STRUCT<F1 INT> KEY`). See the next two sections

nodes.bodyText:
This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                registers new schemas with {{ site.sr }}, as necessary while `JSON` requires you
          
          
            
                registers new schemas with {{ site.sr }} as necessary, while `JSON` requires you
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -106,9 +111,10 @@ Avro-formatted data. If you want to use Protobuf- or JSON-formatted data,
 substitute `PROTOBUF`, `JSON` or `JSON_SR` for `AVRO` in each statement.
 
 !!! note
-    ksqlDB handles the `JSON` and `JSON_SR` formats differently. While the
-    `JSON` format is capable of _reading_ the schema from {{ site.sr }},
-    `JSON_SR` both reads and registers new schemas, as necessary.
+    ksqlDB handles the `JSON` and `JSON_SR` formats differently. `JSON_SR` reads and 
+    registers new schemas with {{ site.sr }}, as necessary while `JSON` requires you

nodes.bodyText: Is it valid to have spaces here? I thought the default delimiter was a comma (with no space)?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -127,11 +129,11 @@ split into columns.
 For example, given a SQL statement such as:
 
 ```sql
-CREATE STREAM x (ID BIGINT, NAME STRING, AGE INT) WITH (VALUE_FORMAT='DELIMITED', ...);
+CREATE STREAM x (ORGID BIGINT KEY, ID BIGINT KEY, NAME STRING, AGE INT) WITH (FORMAT='DELIMITED', ...);
 ```
 
-ksqlDB splits a value of `120, bob, 49` into the three fields with `ID` of
-`120`, `NAME` of `bob` and `AGE` of `49`.
+ksqlDB splits a key of `120, 21` and a value of `bob, 49` into the four fields (two keys and two values)

@@ -127,11 +129,11 @@ split into columns.
 For example, given a SQL statement such as:
 
 ```sql
-CREATE STREAM x (ID BIGINT, NAME STRING, AGE INT) WITH (VALUE_FORMAT='DELIMITED', ...);
+CREATE STREAM x (ORGID BIGINT KEY, ID BIGINT KEY, NAME STRING, AGE INT) WITH (FORMAT='DELIMITED', ...);
 ```
 
-ksqlDB splits a value of `120, bob, 49` into the three fields with `ID` of
-`120`, `NAME` of `bob` and `AGE` of `49`.
+ksqlDB splits a key of `120, 21` and a value of `bob, 49` into the four fields (two keys and two values)
